bibl.title: Letter from Hugh H. Trout to Philip Showalter Hench, April 21, 1948

div1.p: Trout informs Hench that an account of Cooke's yellow fever experiences might be published.

div1.head: Letter from Hugh H. Trout to Philip Showalter Hench, April 21, 1948
div1.opener:
JEFFERSON HOSPITAL
ROANOKE, VA.
April 21, 1948
SURGICAL DEPARTMENT
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
102 - 2nd Avenue,
Rochester, Minnesota.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Knowing your interest in Dr. Cook and his experience with the
yellow fever episode, I thought it would interest you to hear that I think we
have started something by which we can arrange for him to have his experiences
published.

Last night I went to Lexington and made a little talk before the
Rotary Club about it, and they promised to appoint a committee and see if we
could not get a ghost writer to come to Lexington, spend a few days, and as-
sist Dr. Cook in writing up his experiences.

Mr. Bacon of the Lippincott Company is very much interested in
this, and I think we could have the article published in the American Practitioner,
which the Lippincott Company publishes. However, the whole affair is in the
hands of the Rotary Club, and you know very well what committees don't do!

I certainly enjoyed your address given in Cleveland at the unveil-
ing of Dean Cornwell's painting. Hoping to have the pleasure of seeing you in
this part of the world sometime and assuring you I will let you know if anything
develops in the Lexington situation, I remain
div1.closer: Yours very truly, Hugh H. Trout, Sr., M. D. HHT, Sr/me
